The Bulletin of the European Union reports on the activities of the Commission and the other Community institutions. It is produced by the Secretariat-General of the European Commission and published 10 times a year. The following reference system is used: the first digit indicates the part number, the second digit the chapter number and the subsequent digit or digits the point number. Citations should therefore read as follows: Bull. 1/2-1994, point 1.1.1 or 2.2.3. The Bulletin is available on the Europa server (http://europa.eu/bulletin/en/welcome.htm). A great deal of additional information on the European Union is available on the Internet. It can be accessed through the Europa server (http://europa.eu). 8 Bull. EU 10-2008 I — Brussels European Council Brussels, 15 and 16 October I.1. The full text of the Presidency conclusions and annexes are reproduced below ( → points I.2 to I.16). Presidency conclusions I.2. The European Council met on 15 and 16 October 2008, against a backdrop of international economic and financial crisis. The European Council expressed its resolve to act in a concerted and comprehensive man- ner to protect the European financial system and depos- itors. The European Council reaffirmed the objective of an overall agreement on the ‘energy/climate change’ issue before the end of the year. It agreed to speed up work on energy security. It adopted the European Pact on Immigration and Asylum. In the external sphere, it took stock of Russia’s implementation of the agree- ment of 8 September, the situation in Georgia and the EU’s relations with its eastern neighbours. The Euro- pean Council heard the Irish Prime Minister’s analysis of the Irish referendum on the Lisbon Treaty; it will return to the issue in December. The European Coun- cil endorsed the composition of the Reflection Group on the Future of the Union. I.3. The meeting of the European Council was pre- ceded by an exposé by the President of the European Parliament, Mr Hans-Gert Pöttering, followed by an exchange of views. Economic and financial situation References: Council conclusions on EU arrangements for financial stability: Bull. 10-2007, point 1.10.4 Council conclusions on a coordinated EU response to the economic slowdown: point 1.7.6 of this Bul- letin Council conclusions on financial stability and financial supervision: point 1.7.5 of this Bulletin Council conclusions on the EU supervisory framework and financial stability arrangements: Bull. 5-2008, point 1.11.4 European Parliament resolution with recommen- dations to the Commission on Lamfalussy follow- up: future structure of supervision: point 1.11.5 of this Bulletin I.4. 1. Faced with the financial crisis, the European Council affirms that it is determined to take coordi- nated and thorough action to restore the smooth run- ning of the financial system, thus ensuring the normal and effective financing of the economy and returning to the path towards growth and employment. 2. The European Council welcomes the measures taken by the European Central Bank and by the relevant national central banks since the beginning of the finan- cial crisis, and the fact that they have coordinated their efforts well with the central banks of partner countries. The liquidity of the financial system will be ensured by all the authorities so as to maintain confidence and stability. 3. The European Council welcomes the concerted action plan of the euro-area countries of 12 October, of which it endorses the principles (14239/08). It also welcomes the measures adopted by the Member States, whether or not they belong to the euro area, in con- formity with the principles of that plan and in compli- ance with the Treaty. The national measures already approved by the Commission continue to be applica- ble. The European Council calls on the Member States to ensure that their future national measures also respect those principles, and to take account of the pos- sible effect of their decisions on the other Member States. 4. The European Council reaffirms its commitment that in all circumstances the necessary measures will be taken to preserve the stability of the financial system, to support the major financial institutions, to avoid bankruptcies and to protect savers’ deposits. Inter alia, such measures aim, in conjunction with the central banks and supervisory authorities, to ensure sufficient liquidity for financial institutions, to facilitate their funding, and to provide them with capital resources so that they can continue to finance the economy prop- erly. The European Council considers that measures to support financial institutions in difficulty should go hand in hand with measures to protect taxpayers, to secure accountability on the part of executives and shareholders and to protect the legitimate interests of other market players.

Presidency conclusions Bull. EU 10-2008 9 I.5. 5. In the current exceptional circumstances, Euro- pean rules must continue to be implemented in a way that meets the need for speedy and flexible action. The European Council supports the Commission’s imple- mentation, in this spirit, of the rules on competition policy, particularly State aids, while continuing to apply the principles of the single market and the sys- tem of State aids. 6. To enable speedy and effective action to be taken in a crisis situation, an informal warning, information- exchange and evaluation mechanism (the financial cri- sis cell) will be established. This mechanism will bring together representatives of the Presidency-in-office, the President of the Commission, the President of the ECB (in conjunction with the other European central banks), the President of the Eurogroup and the governments of the Member States. It will be based on existing administrative structures, may be activated at any time by a Member State faced with a crisis and will ensure that information is provided immediately and in con- fidence to the institutions and all the Member States. It will also help to ensure smooth coordination of actions taken or to be taken. The European Council requests the Council to finalise as soon as possible the procedures for the setting up and operation of the financial crisis cell. 7. Maintaining confidence in the financial and banking system and protecting the interests of depositors and investors also requires rigorous implementation by financial institutions of recommendations on the trans- parency of their commitments and risks. 8. The European Council stresses the need to strengthen the supervision of the European financial sector, partic- ularly cross-border groups, and to implement urgently the Ecofin Council’s roadmap, with a view to improving the coordination of supervision at European level. In this context, the European Council welcomes the setting up of a high-level group by the Commission. To begin with, the European Council invites national supervisors to meet at least once a month, to exchange information. The European Council supports the speeding up of work to strengthen the rules on stability, including work on the capital requirements directive. In addition, the European Council calls for a speedy examination of the Commission’s forthcoming legisla- tive proposal to strengthen the rules on rating agencies and their supervision at European level. It calls for speedy decisions on the development of European rules on the security of deposits to ensure that savers are protected. The European Council welcomes the deci- sion taken concerning the accounting standards appli- cable to financial institutions and their interpretation. Furthermore, the European Council calls for more general consideration, in consultation with the inter- national partners, of the effects that fair value and mark-to-market accounting would have on financial institutions and on the market, including their pro- cyclical effects. 9. In order to learn from the crisis and restore public confidence, the European Council makes a firm call for accountability on the part of all those involved in the financial system, particularly the banking sector. It emphasises that the real performance of company executives should be reflected in their remuneration, including their severance pay (‘golden parachutes’), which should be in line with their actual contribution to the success of the company. Likewise, care should be taken to ensure that earnings from stock options or the system of remuneration, especially in the financial sec- tor, do not lead to excessive risk-taking or extreme con- centration on short-term objectives. The European Council calls on the Member States to work to put these principles into practice and calls on the Council to report back on the decisions taken by the end of the year. I.6. 10. Beyond the financial sector, the European Council underlines its determination to take the nec- essary steps to support growth and employment. It invites the Commission to make appropriate proposals by the end of the year, in particular to preserve the international competitiveness of European industry. The European Council emphasises that continued structural reform is more important than ever, to help restore growth and improve employment in Europe. Support for economic activity involves an adequate level of finance. The European Council welcomes the European Investment Bank’s decision to mobilise EUR 30 billion to support European SMEs and its commitment to step up its ability to intervene in infra- structure projects. It calls on the EIB to assume a greater share of risk in the financing of SMEs. I.7. 11. Budget policies must continue to be in line with the revised Stability and Growth Pact, which should also be applied in a manner which reflects the current exceptional circumstances, as provided for in its rules. I.8. 12. The European Union must work with its inter- national partners on a genuine, all-encompassing reform of the international financial system based on the prin- ciples of transparency, sound banking, responsibility, integrity and world governance. The aim is to take early decisions on transparency, global standards of regula- tion, cross-border supervision and crisis management, to avoid conflicts of interest and to create an early warn- ing system, so as to engender confidence among savers and investors in every country. The Union will quickly take appropriate initiatives in consultation with its main partners and the relevant international financial institu- tions. These initiatives will be carefully prepared within the EU. I.9. 13. The European Council expresses its solidarity with the efforts made by Iceland, a country which is closely integrated into the EU single market through the EEA Agreement and which requires the support of

Presidency conclusions 10 Bull. EU 10-2008 the international community; it expects Iceland to hon- our its international commitments. I.10. 14. The European Council took note of a report drawn up by the Presidency, in cooperation with the Commission, on oil price volatility. It calls on the Council to press ahead with its discussions on this issue and, in the immediate future, requests the Com- mission to take the necessary action to promote the transparency of commercial oil stocks, as well as energy efficiency in conjunction with the European Investment Bank in particular. Treaty of Lisbon Reference: European Council conclusions: Bull. 6-2008, point I.3 I.11. 15. The European Council, recalling its conclu- sions of June 2008, took note of the analysis of the results of the referendum on the Treaty of Lisbon pre- sented by the Irish Taoiseach, Mr Brian Cowen. The Irish government will continue its consultations with a view to contributing to finding a way to resolve the sit- uation. On that basis, the European Council agreed to return to this matter at its meeting in December 2008 with a view to defining the elements of a solution and a common path to be followed. Energy and climate change References: European Council conclusions: Bull. 3-2007, points I.9 to I.12; Bull. 3-2008, points I.14 to I.18 I.12. 16. The European Council confirms its determi- nation to honour the ambitious commitments on cli- mate and energy policy which it approved in March 2007 and March 2008. In this connection, it requests the Presidency and the Commission to organise inten- sive work over the next few weeks in order to enable the European Council in December 2008 to decide on appropriate responses to the challenge of applying that package in a rigorously established cost-effective man- ner to all sectors of the European economy and all Member States, having regard to each Member State’s specific situation. Energy security References: Proposal for a directive of the European Parlia- ment and of the Council amending Directive 2003/54/EC concerning common rules for the internal market in electricity: OJ C 4, 9.1.2008; COM(2007) 528; Bull. 9-2007, point 1.24.1 Proposal for a directive of the European Parlia- ment and of the Council amending Directive 2003/55/EC concerning common rules for the internal market in natural gas: OJ C 4, 9.1.2008; COM(2007) 529; Bull. 9-2007, point 1.24.1 Proposal for a regulation of the European Par- liament and of the Council establishing an agency for the cooperation of energy regulators: OJ C 4, 9.1.2008; COM(2007) 530; Bull. 9-2007, point 1.24.1 Proposal for a regulation of the European Par- liament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1228/2003 on conditions for access to the network for cross-border exchanges in electricity: OJ C 4, 9.1.2008; COM(2007) 531; Bull. 9-2007, point 1.24.1 Proposal for a regulation of the European Par- liament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1775/2005 on conditions for access to the natural gas transmission networks: OJ C 4, 9.1.2008; COM(2007) 532; Bull. 9-2007, point 1.24.1 Commission communication — ‘Action plan for energy efficiency: realising the potential’: OJ C 78, 11.4.2007; COM(2006) 545; Bull. 10-2006, point 1.23.5 Commission communication on ‘A European strategic energy plan (SET-plan): towards a low carbon future’: OJ C 55, 28.2.2008; COM(2007) 723; Bull. 11-2007, point 1.24.1 I.13. 17. Security of energy supply is a priority for the European Union. It involves the responsibility and sol- idarity of all the Member States. To this end, taking account of the report submitted by the Presidency (14090/08), the European Council has decided to step up the work in progress, by adopting the following guidelines and requesting the Commission to submit relevant proposals or initiatives, where necessary, to: (a) finalise the legislative package on the internal mar- ket in electricity and gas before the end of the legisla- tive period; (b) expedite the implementation of the European energy efficiency action plan and the strategic energy technology plan; (c) pursue with determination the diversification of energy sources, to which the measures in the energy and climate package contribute directly; (d) promote improvement in the working of the mar- ket, in particular through greater transparency on flows and stockpiles and through sharing information on long-term requirements and resources; (e) develop crisis mechanisms to deal with temporary disruptions to supplies;

Presidency conclusions Bull. EU 10-2008 11 (f) strengthen and add to critical infrastructure, partic- ularly trans-European energy transport networks and liquefied natural gas terminals. Particular attention will be paid to interconnections and to the connection of the most isolated European countries, to the interface of European networks with supply infrastructure and to the need to diversify both sources and routes. The European Council supports the Commission initiative of establishing a plan of action to speed up intercon- nections in the Baltic region. A schedule of work will be drawn up for this purpose before the end of the year; (g) develop the Union’s energy relations with producer and transit countries with a view to securing stability of supply and diversifying its energy sources and sup- ply routes. In this connection, the European Council welcomes the energy security initiatives taken by sev- eral Member States and, in particular, the meeting with the Caspian Sea countries and transit countries which will be organised by the Czech Presidency in the spring of 2009. 18. The European Council will return to this issue at its meeting in March 2009 to take stock of progress, in the light too of the Commission’s forthcoming strate- gic energy review, and to adopt the necessary decisions. European Pact on Immigration and Asylum Reference: European Council conclusions: Bull. 6-2008, point I.4 I.14. 19. The European Council adopted the European Pact on Immigration and Asylum (13440/08), which expresses the commitment of the European Union and its Member States to conduct a fair, effective and con- sistent policy for dealing with the challenges and opportunities which migration represents. The pact will henceforth form the basis, for the Union and its Mem- ber States, of a common immigration and asylum pol- icy, guided by a spirit of solidarity between Member States and cooperation with third countries. This com- mon policy must be founded on proper management of migratory flows, in the interests not only of the host countries but also of the countries of origin and of the migrants themselves. 20. The fundamental principles set out in the pact are reflected in a series of measures which will have to be implemented immediately at both EU and national level. Moreover, these principles will also inform the future work programme of the European Union, which will be proposed by the Commission in May 2009 with a view to finalisation under the Swedish Presidency. Implementation of the pact will be the subject of an annual debate starting with the European Council in June 2010. Follow-up to the European Council of 1 September 2008 References: European Council conclusions: Bull. 9-2008, points I.1 and I.2 EU–Ukraine summit: Bull. 9-2008, point 1.35.10 Council conclusions on relations with the Repub- lic of Moldova: point 1.35.14 of this Bulletin Council conclusions on Georgia and Russia: point 1.35.19 of this Bulletin I.15. 21. The European Council notes with satisfaction that Russian troops have withdrawn from the zones adjacent to South Ossetia and Abkhazia as an essential additional step in the implementation of the agreements of 12 August and 8 September, as well as the launch- ing in Geneva of the international discussions provided for by those agreements. The European Council is ask- ing the Commission and the Council to continue a full in-depth evaluation of EU–Russia relations with a view to the forthcoming summit, scheduled to take place in Nice on 14 November. It will be taken into account in the further negotiations for a new partnership agree- ment with Russia. 22. The European Union is resolved, in particular through its neighbourhood policy, to continue sup- porting its eastern neighbours in their efforts to achieve economic modernisation and democratisation. The European Council stresses in this respect the impor- tance of the outcome of the EU–Ukraine summit in Paris and calls for relations between the Union and the Republic of Moldova and Georgia to be strengthened in accordance with the Council conclusions of 13 Oc- tober. It is instructing the Council to conduct an initial examination of the proposals for a future ‘eastern part- nership’ of the European Union which the Commis- sion intends to submit in November. Reflection group Reference: European Council conclusions: Bull. 12-2007, point I.5 I.16. 23. The European Council approved the proposal by the chairman of the Reflection Group and its two deputy chairmen concerning the composition of the group, as annexed to these conclusions. The group will start work as soon as possible and will conduct its dis- cussions in accordance with the mandate adopted by the European Council in December 2007. The General Secretariat of the Council will provide the group with material and logistical support.

Bull. EU 10-2008 13 1. Institutional questions 1.1.1. The European Council heard the Irish Prime Minister’s analysis of the Irish referendum on the Lisbon Treaty. It will return to the issue in December, with a view to defining the elements of a solution and a common path to be followed ( → point I.11). Transparency 1.1.2. Report from the Commission on the appli- cation in 2007 of Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 regarding public access to European Parliament, Council and Commission documents. Previous report: OJ C 106, 26.4.2008; COM(2007) 841; Bull. 12-2007, point 1.1.3 Reference: Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council: OJ L 145, 31.5.2001; Bull. 5-2001, point 1.1.2 Adopted by the Commission on 10 October. This report contains seven sections dealing with the following topics: transparency policy; Internet registers and sites; cooperation with the other institutions and Member States; analysis of access applications; application of exceptions to the right of access; complaints to the European Ombudsman; court actions. The overall picture that emerges from analysis of access applications is that a large proportion of them relate to Com- mission monitoring of the application of Com- munity law. In many cases, access was applied for in order to obtain documents likely to support the applicant’s position in a complaint or an administrative or judicial action. The exception relating to protection of the Commission’s deci- sion-making process is mainly cited to protect decision-making on individual issues. The excep- tion concerning the protection of commercial interests, which has shown a marked increase, is mainly cited in connection with requests for access to competition policy documents. According to the Commission, it is important to note that the Court of Justice has overturned the Court of First Instance’s (CFI) interpretation as regards the right of a Member State to oppose the disclosure of documents originating from it, in that the Member State is required to state the rea- sons for its objection with reference to the excep- tions provided for in the regulation. The Commission underlined that the CFI has clarified a number of points: ¡ in cases where the hearing has not yet taken place, the ‘court proceedings’ exception applies without the institution having to carry out a con- crete examination of each document concerned; ¡ the ‘investigation’ exception in respect of infringements of Community law applies even after the hearing and until the judgment is handed down. As a rule, once the Court has handed down its judgment, this reason no longer applies; ¡ access to documents containing personal data falls within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 1049/ 2001. The exception under Article 4(1)(b) concerns only personal data capable of actually and specifi- cally undermining the protection of privacy and the integrity of the individual. EU 10-2008 European Parliament resolution on the strategy for the simplification of the regulatory environ- ment: OJ C 187 E, 24.7.2008; Bull. 9-2007, point 1.2.1 European Parliament resolution on better regu- lation in the European Union: OJ C 187 E, 24.7.2008; Bull. 9-2007, point 1.2.3 Commission communication — ‘Second strate- gic review of better regulation in the European Union’: OJ C 207, 14.8.2008; COM(2008) 32; Bull. 1/2-2008, point 1.2.1 Commission working document — ‘Reducing administrative burdens in the European Union — 2007 progress report and 2008 outlook’: OJ C 202, 8.8.2008; COM(2008) 35; Bull. 1/2-2008, point 1.2.2 Commission working document — ‘Second progress report on the strategy for simplifying the regulatory environment’: OJ C 202, 8.8.2008; COM(2008) 33; Bull. 1/2-2008, point 1.2.3 Commission communication — ‘2008 fast track actions to reduce administrative burdens in the Euro- pean Union’: OJ C 202, 8.8.2008; COM(2008) 141; Bull. 3-2008, point 1.2.3 Adopted by the European Parliament on 21 Oc- tober. Parliament supports the Commission’s objective of improving the quality of Commu- nity legislation and reducing the legislative bur- den, including abolishing legislation that is unnecessary, hampers growth and inhibits inno- vation. It declared itself in favour of a principle- based legislation and expects quality to prevail over quantity. In the context of the efforts to bring about better lawmaking, Parliament stressed the importance of the principles of sub- sidiarity and proportionality, both in reducing unnecessary bureaucratic burdens on Member States and in securing broader acceptance among EU citizens for those measures which, in keep- ing with both principles, can only be taken at Community level. It deplored the fact that, despite having improved its procedures, the Commission continues to draw up separate doc- uments relating to simplification and ‘better law- making’ that contain non-identical lists of sim- plification strategies, which makes it difficult to get a complete overview of the strategy. Accord- ing to Parliament, the proliferation of such doc- uments must be avoided. It therefore called on the Commission to draw up a single annual doc- ument. In addition, Parliament confirmed its wish that the Commission adopt recasting as an ordi- nary legislative technique, even when the ‘revi- sion’ of the current text is being proposed, so as to make it possible to have, for each initiative, a complete overview of the text, including the spe- cific amendments, clearly indicating which parts are new and which parts remain unchanged. Finally, Parliament emphasised that the Com- mission’s target of reducing administrative bur- dens by 25% by 2012 should be a net target, meaning that reductions in certain areas must not be nullified by new administrative burdens imposed elsewhere. OJ L 304, 14.11.2008 Agencies 1.1.6. Council conclusions on the Court of Audi- tors Special Report No 5/2008 entitled ‘The European Union’s agencies: getting results’.

Institutional questions Bull. EU 10-2008 15 Reference: Court of Auditors Special Report No 5/2008: Bull. 6-2008, point 1.38.17 Adopted by the Council on 13 October. The Coun- cil underlined the importance of the principles of budget discipline and sound financial management to be applied to the financial management of decentralised agencies. On another note, the Council was concerned that according to the gen- eral findings of the Court of Auditors, the audited decentralised agencies do not plan their activities adequately nor do most of them have at their dis- posal sound tools for monitoring their activities, and that the reporting of the activities and the evaluation of the results need to be improved. It thus called on the agencies concerned to remedy this situation. Moreover, for those which have still not done it, decentralised agencies should produce a strategy document in the form of a multiannual work programme, with clear objectives and per- formance indicators of the impact and the out- comes that they aim to achieve. Decentralised agencies should also set up management control instruments linked to their work programmes and to their budgets, including all allocated resources, in order to develop the reports into genuine instru- ments of governance. In addition, the Council invited the Commission to continue providing assistance to the agencies in the most appropriate form and underlined in that context that particu- lar attention should be paid to dissemination of best practices, proper application of procedures for awarding contracts and appropriate training for the members of agencies’ governing bodies. Finally, the Council invited the Court of Auditors to keep it updated on the progress made by the decentralised agencies and to extend its audits to cover executive agencies. 1.1.7. Bull. EU 10-2008 17 3. Sustainable development General 1.3.1. European Economic and Social Commit- tee own-initiative opinion — ‘Beyond GDP — measurements for sustainable development’. Adopted by the European Economic and Social Committee on 22 October. The Committee con- siders that GDP is an important indicator of eco- nomic growth, but as an instrument for guiding policy it is inadequate to meet the challenges of the 21st century. According to it, what is needed above all is an instrument that will show how far Europe still is from achieving a sustainable and socially inclusive economy. Since two different issues are concerned — sustainability and wel- fare — two indicators are actually needed. There is an indicator for measuring sustainability and sustainability trends: namely the ecological foot- print which despite its shortcomings is the best available overall indicator on sustainable envi- ronmental development. The challenge is to develop an indicator for social development that can measure the various dimensions of quality of life in a way that provides a realistic picture. According to the Committee, a practicable and scientifically reliable quality-of-life indicator must be founded on the six following matters: ¡ physical integrity and health; ¡ material wealth; ¡ access to public services; ¡ social participation and incomer integration; ¡ leisure time; ¡ quality of the environment.

Since mid-2006, the Hungarian authorities have made significant efforts to correct the country’s accu- mulated external and internal imbalances. Despite the tangible results achieved over the last two years, including the significant reduction in the general government deficit and the gradual decrease in the current account deficit, the Hun- garian financial markets came under severe stress as of early October 2008. The authorities rapidly announced a comprehensive policy package designed to restore investor confidence and alle- viate the stress experienced in financial markets. However, as a rapid deterioration in the capital and financial accounts induced by financial mar- kets turbulences could be expected in 2008 and especially 2009, the country will need substan- tial financial support in this period, possibly in the order of EUR 20 billion until the end of 2009. Thus, medium-term financial assistance for Hungary under the balance of payments facility for Member States appears to be appropriate under the current circumstances. The EU finan- cial assistance is provided in support of the strong commitment by the Hungarian authorities to implement a comprehensive economic policy programme, designed to restore investor confi- dence and alleviate the stress experienced in recent weeks in Hungarian financial markets. This programme will be included in the conver- gence programme update. The EU assistance would also help ensure full consistency of cur- rent policies supported by the whole financing package with EU policy recommendations. Eco- nomic policy conditionality would include reform of fiscal governance and support the increased ambition in terms of deficit reduction ensuring that the planned correction of the excessive deficit (by 2009 at the latest) is respected. Regulation to be amended: Council Regulation (EC) No 332/2002 establishing a single facility providing medium-term financial assistance for Member States’ balances of payments: OJ L 53, 23.2.2002; Bull. 1/2-2002, point 1.3.24 Adopted by the Commission on 30 October. Coun- cil regulation (EC) No 332/2002 established a facility providing medium-term financial assis- tance for Member States’ balances of payments. This facility implements the mechanism foreseen by Article 119 of the EC Treaty, whereby the Community can grant a mutual assistance to a Member State ‘in difficulties or when seriously threatened with difficulties as regards its balance of payments either as a result of an overall dise- quilibrium in its balance of payments or as a result of the type of currency at its disposal’, provided this Member State does not belong to the euro area. This regulation lowered the threshold exist- ing in the former regulation from EUR 16 billion to EUR 12 billion. This decision was consis- tent with the significant reduction in the poten- tial number of recipients, with only three Mem- ber States outside the euro area at that time. Nevertheless, the evolution of the international financial context leads to the conclusion today that it may not be sufficient, should several Member States need a significant Community medium- term financial support. It is therefore proposed to raise the ceiling of the amount of loans to be granted to Member States under this facility to EUR 25 billion, with a view to increasing the capacity of the EU significantly to answer the potential needs of Member States outside the euro area. It is also proposed to establish a specific pro- cedure for revising the ceiling when there is an urgent need to take such a decision. Taking account of the current extraordinary stress in global financial markets and the potential impact of the economic situation, the Council agreed on the need to continue pursuing a coordinated response at the European level, within the scope of Member States’ respective responsibilities, to adjust their response to their individual situation, coupled with Member States’ flexibility. In addi- tion, according to the Council, it is necessary to continue implementing sound structural reforms at the national level in order to strengthen resilience to future crises. In this context, the Council recalled the urgency to enhance banks’ practices for the evaluation of exposures and urged supervisors and accounting standards- setters to ensure that the financial reporting frame- work functions properly, with clear guidelines on valuation that can be applied consistently across institutions. In respect of the convergence of supervisory practices, the Council agreed to make EU-wide common reporting formats for a single set of data requirements and reporting dates, which is much needed, both to ensure an efficient and convergent supervision and to reduce admin- istrative burden for groups operational by 2012. By this date, there should be a common set of reporting formats and no extra time should be allowed. 1.7.6. Council conclusions on a coordinated EU response to the economic slowdown. References: Council conclusions on EU arrangements for financial stability: Bull. 10-2007, point 1.10.4 Council conclusions on financial stability and financial supervision: point 1.7.5 of this Bulletin Adopted by the Council on 7 October. The Coun- cil noticed that, to a large extent, Member States are facing common shocks. Therefore, the eco- nomic situation calls for a coordinated response at the EU level, based on a common understand- ing of the problems at hand and taking into account common features and national specifici- ties. The Council proposed a strategy for EU Member States which could be built on the fol- lowing elements: ¡ at the macroeconomic and structural level, ensure domestic policies are in place to support growth in a sustainable manner: European macro- economic policies need to respond in an appropri- ate and consistent way to the shocks stemming from the global economy. These shocks are to a large extent faced by all Member States, even though the precise effect on the economies may differ across economies and across groups. The Council considers that, at the current juncture, designing policies which help curb inflation, thereby protecting the purchasing power of people, fostering sustainable growth and helping restore an environment supportive to monetary policy is key; ¡ restore confidence on financial markets and avoid excessive tightening of credit toward SMEs in the EU: the financial turmoil is a core compo- nent of the current global economic slowdown. In the short term, the key response remains restoring confidence in the financial system through full implementation of the October 2007 roadmap. In this respect, according to the Coun- cil, financial institutions are continuously mak- ing efforts to improve disclosure of their expo- sure to risks. Nevertheless, those efforts still need to be properly assessed by banking supervisors within the Committee of European Banking Supervisors; ¡ on the external front, contribute to a more favourable environment: in response to the cur- rent global crisis in the financial sector, Europe should continue to act proactively in international fora, notably at the Financial Stability Forum and the IMF. The Council also agreed to increase the political impetus to the economic and financial dimension of the Union’s relations with its part- ners, notably on the occasion of bilateral summits. 1.7.7. European Economic and Social Commit- tee opinion on ‘Ethical and social dimension of European financial institutions’. Adopted by the European Economic and Social Committee on 23 October. The Committee con- sidered that the grave financial crisis and the wel- come defeat of ‘casino capitalism’ could provide an opportunity to adopt more appropriate meas- ures for safeguarding the financial system in the future while simultaneously relaunching the economy. It specified that a broad-based effort was required, commensurate with the danger that the virus detected in the financial sector might spread to the real economy as a whole. The Com- mittee noticed investment in infrastructure, in ‘green investment’ such as energy efficiency, renewable resources, and innovation and research could help bolster demand. It emphasised that a specific organisation shown to have given up, at least in part, on a structural and permanent basis, the principle of maximising profit in order to pro- mote initiatives of an ethical or social nature should be entitled to come under tax and regula- tory rules that are different from the general ones, except in the case of prudential rules, at least in part. Finally, the Committee observed that by ensuring Member States do not adopt measures that would distort competition, the Commission can help protect diversity in the supply of finan- cial, banking and insurance services.

Economic and monetary policy 24 Bull. EU 10-2008 1.7.8. Communication from the Commission — ‘From financial crisis to recovery: a European framework for action’. Reference: Council conclusions on a coordinated EU response to the economic slowdown: point 1.7.6 of this Bulletin Adopted by the Commission on 29 October. According to the Commission, the unprecedented crisis in international financial markets has cre- ated major challenges for the EU. Coordinated action at EU level by all 27 Member States has been effective in stabilising Europe’s banking system. However, the Commission recalled that the financial crisis is not yet over and is already feeding into a serious downturn, affecting the wider economy. Europe’s strength lies in its sol- idarity and its ability to act together. All Member States will be affected, albeit in different ways and to different degrees and acting jointly means a more effective and credible response. Thus, according to the Commission, the EU should build on this success and decide to tackle the next stages of the crisis in a united, coordinated man- ner, turning these challenges into opportunities and adding selected short-term measures to the Lisbon strategy for growth and jobs. This com- munication sets out an overall EU recovery action plan/framework based on three points: ¡ a new financial market architecture at EU level; ¡ dealing with the impact on the real economy; ¡ a global response to the financial crisis. On 26 November, the Commission will propose a more detailed EU recovery framework, under the umbrella of the Lisbon strategy for growth and jobs, bringing together a series of targeted short-term initiatives designed to help counter adverse effects on the wider economy and adapt- ing the medium and long-term measures of the Lisbon strategy to take account of the crisis. The proposal provides for a modern and coherent legal framework for issuing electronic money, with the aim of promoting the emergence of a true single market for electronic money services in the EU. The main innovations proposed are as follows: ¡ a technologically neutral and simpler defini- tion of ‘electronic money’, covering all situations where the payment service provider (an e-money institution or a credit institution) issues a prepaid stored value in exchange of funds. Electronic money is therefore defined as monetary value stored electronically on receipt of funds and which is used for making payment transactions. This definition covers e-money held on payment devices in the holder’s possession (pre-paid cards or electronic purse) or stored remotely at a server (network or software money); ¡ a new prudential regime, ensuring greater consistency between prudential requirements of electronic money institutions and payment insti- tutions under the payment services directive 2007/ 64/EC. Report from the Commission to the European Parliament and the Council on the final evaluation of the Fiscalis programme 2003–07 in accordance with Article 15 of Decision 2235/ 2002/EC of the European Parliament and the Council of 3 December 2002 adopting a Com- munity programme to improve the operation of taxation systems in the internal market (Fiscalis programme 2003–07). Reference: Decision No 2235/2002/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council: OJ L 341, 17.12.2002; Bull. 12-2002, point 1.3.45 Adopted by the Commission on 9 October. This final evaluation covers the entire period 2003–07. It concludes that the programme succeeded in improving the operation of taxation systems in the internal market by increasing cooperation between participating countries, their administra- tions and tax officials. In the area of indirect tax- ation, particularly value added tax and excise duties, the programme’s objectives were: to enable officials to achieve a high common stan- dard of understanding of Community law and of its implementation in Member States; to secure efficient, effective and extensive cooperation among Member States; to improve administrative procedures. In the area of direct taxation, Fiscalis was intended to support information exchange in the field of mutual assistance and to raise aware- ness of the applicable Community law. For taxes on insurance premiums the goals of improving cooperation between Member States and of ensuring better application of the existing rules remain valid. Finally, the programme contributed to satisfying the special needs of candidate coun- tries so that they could take the necessary meas- ures for accession in the field of tax legislation and administrative capacity. Communication from the Commission to the Council, the European Parliament, the Euro- pean Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions — ‘Towards world- class clusters in the European Union: imple- menting the broad-based innovation strategy’. References: Commission communication — ‘Putting knowl- edge into practice: a broad-based innovation strat- egy for the European Union’: COM(2006) 502; Bull. 9-2006, point 1.12.4 Council conclusions on innovation and compet- itiveness: Bull. 12-2006, point 1.12.2 European Council conclusions: Bull. 3-2008, point I.5 and following Commission communication — ‘Think small first — A Small Business Act for Europe’: COM(2008) 394; Bull. 6-2008, point 1.13.2 Adopted by the Commission on 17 October. According to the Commission, sustainable growth and job creation in the EU increasingly depends on excellence and innovation as the main drivers of European competitiveness. Recognis- ing this fact, in 2006 the EU adopted a broad- based innovation strategy which identified strengthening clusters in Europe as one of the nine strategic priorities for successfully promot- ing innovation. A cluster can be broadly defined as a group of firms, related economic actors and institutions that are located near each other and have reached a sufficient scale to develop spe- cialised expertise, services, resources, suppliers and skills. Cluster policies are designed and implemented at local, regional and national level, depending on their scope and ambition. The Commission considers that it is the role of the Community to facilitate and add to such efforts, notably by: improving the framework conditions; promoting research and education excellence and entrepreneurship; fostering better linkages between industry (especially SMEs) and research; encouraging mutual policy learning and cluster cooperation across the EU. In this respect, it considers that the further completion of the inter- nal market and the development of a competitive European research area are crucial. This commu- nication outlines a policy framework for better complementarities and synergies between the dif- ferent policy levels with a view to supporting the development of more world-class clusters in the EU. In particular, the Commission wanted to: establish within 2008 the high-level European Cluster Policy Group; continue to facilitate the policy dialogue between public authorities as it is currently taking place within the European Cluster Alliance; better coordinate and streamline existing Community instruments (developed under the new cohesion policy, the seventh frame- work programme for research and development (FP7) and the competitiveness and innovation programme (CIP)). The Committee welcomed the Com- mission communication on pre-commercial pro- curement as a satisfactory first introduction to the basic concept and the way in which it can be organised, although there are certain oversights with regard to the actual implementation of the procedure proposed. It believes that designing and drawing up very technical versions of public tenders to promote innovation calls for particular knowledge and skills which local and regional authorities do not generally have. The Committee noted that even if pre-commercial procurement of R & D services ultimately proves successful, it will still be difficult to mobilise and activate citizens politically at local and regional level. It thinks that the Commission should provide a clear and detailed guide, as well as training opportunities, to contracting local and regional authorities on how to use pre-commercial pro- curement of R & D services so that European law is not infringed. The Committee urged the Com- mission to demonstrate that pre-commercial pro- curement can be useful for the regional authority managing the tender procedure, even where can- didates are not based in the region. 1.13.4. The framework directive lays down conditions and criteria for introducing implementing measures for particular products, provided they impact significantly on the environment and have high volumes of sales and trade on the internal market plus a clear potential for improvement without entailing excessive costs. Article 16(1) of the eco-design directive specifies that the Commission shall pub- lish an indicative working plan listing the energy- using product groups which will be considered priorities for the adoption of implementing meas- ures for 2009–11. Implementing measures may be proposed after favourable preparatory studies and impact assessments and on the condition that no valid self-regulatory measures are in place. The working plan builds on the environmental priorities and the work done since mid-2005 for the transitional priority product groups listed in Article 16(2) of the directive. Communication from the Commission to the Council, the European Parliament, the Com- mittee of the Regions and the European Eco- nomic and Social Committee — ‘Green Paper on territorial cohesion — Turning territorial diver- sity into strength’. Reference: Proposal for a directive of the Euro- pean Parliament and of the Council on the appli- cation of patients’ rights in cross-border healthcare: COM(2008) 414; Bull. 7/8-2008, point 1.26.9 Adopted by the Commission on 6 October. The EU harbours a rich territorial diversity, which characterises Europe’s economic and social iden- tity. The concept of territorial cohesion, which has been discussed at EU level since the begin- ning of the 1990s, calls for a debate on how this diversity can be turned into an asset that con- tributes to sustainable development across the EU as a whole taking into account the challenges that Europe’s territories will face over the next decades. A shared understanding of these issues could assist in improving the governance of cohe- sion policy, making it more flexible, more capa- ble of adapting to the most appropriate territorial scale, more responsive to local preferences and needs as well as better coordinated with other policies at all levels in conformity with the prin- ciple of subsidiarity. Following the conclusions of the informal meeting of the EU ministers responsible for spatial planning and regional development in Leipzig on 24 and 25 May 2007, inviting the Commission to prepare a report on territorial cohesion by 2008, this Green Paper intends to launch a public debate on territorial cohesion and its implications for policy design. In an increasingly globalised world, the Commit- tee expressed the view that European agriculture cannot do without a powerful European common policy with market regulation mechanisms which, on the one hand, focus on strategic objectives and consumer demand, and which, on the other hand, offer possibilities for regional opportunities and involvement especially on the new challenges, which are economically, socially and environ- mentally sustainable and which contribute to rural prosperity. Furthermore, the Committee feels that if the CAP is to respect the fundamental aspects of European policy, the application of modulation must be primarily based on the conditions of pro- duction before global criteria for competition can be examined. The Committee also expressed con- cern about the lack of financial means for rural development in general and for the new chal- lenges in particular. Under- lining that the carrying out of all CAP measures has a local impact, the Committee finally stressed that the regional level is best placed to achieve optimal results in implementing a common pol- icy, but that distortions of competition between Member States and regions must be avoided. 1.19.4. The trading of emission quotas will apply to the aviation sec- tor as of 2012 and the proposal concerns all flights taking off from or landing on EU territory. The Commission will continue the development of the common aviation area, both by closely monitoring the implementation of exist- ing agreements and by identifying the next poten- tial partners for participation in the project. The western Balkans, Morocco, EEA countries and Switzerland already participate in the common avi- ation area. The Commission has also started com- prehensive air transport negotiations with Ukraine and will soon be launching talks with Israel and Jordan. In addition, it intends to launch compre- hensive air transport negotiations with Algeria and Tunisia, and will closely assess the added value of launching negotiations with Georgia and Moldova. The Council reached an agreement on the key elements of the third legislative package on the internal electricity and gas markets, namely, the conditions for fair competition and the third- country clause: ¡ concerning fair competition: the agreement includes three different unbundling models for production and supply activities, on the one hand, and energy transmission activities on the other, that apply both for gas and electricity. Each Member State will be able to choose one of these options. The Commission’s initial proposal contained two unbundling options: — integral ownership unbundling, meaning that the same company could not simultaneously own a distribution network and produce or supply energy; — allowing for an energy producing and sup- plying company to retain the ownership of the transport network on condition that they hand over the management of the transmission net- work to an independent system operator (ISO). The ISO would be an undertaking that is totally separated from the vertically inte- grated company. The Council approved a third solution whereby the control of the transmission network would be entrusted to an independent transmission network operator (ITO). This option would enable com- panies to retain ownership of transmission net- works provided that they compel to abide by rules and a structure to ensure they operate independ- ently in practice. However, undertakings involved in production or supply activities cannot hold the control over a transmission network operator acquired in a Member State that has opted for full unbundling; ¡ concerning control of networks by third-country companies: the Council reached an agreement on a third-country clause which ensures that third- country companies abide by the same rules as those that apply to EU undertakings and guaran- tee the same opportunities as regards market access and security of energy supply to European and foreign companies. The clause lays down cri- teria for the assessment of investments from third countries and establishes a procedure for certifi- cation of third-country investors wishing to take control of an energy distribution system or oper- ator. It specifies in detail where responsibilities lie and the role of national regulators and of the Commission. 1.25.5. This proposal results from a review of existing legis- lation in the area of consumer contractual rights. It aims at revising Directives 85/577/EEC, 93/13/EEC, 97/7/EC and 1999/44/EC. The pro- posal merges these four directives into a single horizontal instrument regulating the common aspects in a systematic fashion. It also simplifies and updates the existing rules and removes incon- sistencies and gaps. The proposal moves away from the minimum harmonisation approach fol- lowed in the four existing directives (i.e. allow- ing Member States to maintain or adopt stricter national rules than those laid down in the direc- tive) to embrace a full harmonisation approach (i.e. Member States cannot maintain or adopt pro- visions diverging from those laid down in the directive). The proposal contributes to the objec- tives of the Commission as set out in its commu- nication on a single market for 21st century Europe, where the Commission stated that the single market needs to deliver better results and tangible benefits for consumers and SMEs. European Parliament resolution on the suspension of the WTO Doha Round and the future of the Doha Development Agenda. Adopted by the European Parliament on 9 Octo- ber. Parliament recalled that a failure to conclude the Doha Round would add to the current global economic uncertainty and could challenge the credibility of the multilateral trading system, resulting in a shift towards bilateral and regional trade agreements. It called on the EU and the USA, as well as the G20 members as new major economic players, to assume their responsibili- ties in the current negotiations, to fully respect the spirit of the Doha Round, and to make every effort to reach a deal as rapidly as possible. Par- liament noticed that the difficulties relating to the Doha Development Agenda highlight the need to address urgently the question of the WTO reform that aims to make it more effective and transpar- ent and improve its democratic legitimacy, accountability, inclusiveness and integration into the wider architecture of global governance once the Doha Round is over. Council conclusions on Court of Auditors Special Report No 6/2008 — ‘European Com- mission rehabilitation aid following the tsunami and Hurricane Mitch’. Reference: Court of Auditors Special Report No 6/2008 on rehabilitation aid provided by the European Commission after the tsunami and Hur- ricane Mitch: Bull. 6-2008, point 1.38.18 Adopted by the Council on 13 October. While the Council regrets the significant delays in the implementation of rehabilitation aid following Hurricane Mitch, it noted with satisfaction the improvement in the Commission response to the tsunami. This improvement concerns, in particu- lar, the evaluation of needs in conjunction with the beneficiary entities, implementation times, and the usefulness and sustainability of the meas- ures implemented. Progress is still required to be made, however, in particular to ensure efficient monitoring of the implementation of aid and to strengthen the links between the humanitarian response, rehabilitation and development. The Council emphasised the importance of continu- ing to learn lessons from past experience with a view to further improving Commission action in the area of post-disaster rehabilitation aid. Against this background, the Council supports the conclusions and recommendations formulated by the Court of Auditors, commended the readiness of the Commission to implement them and wel- comed the measures already taken by the Com- mission to improve its response to disasters. In particular, the Council invited the Commission to continue to build on its approach adopted after the tsunami, so as to enable the rapid design of rehabilitation projects in conjunction with the beneficiaries in order to enhance ownership and

Development cooperation Bull. EU 10-2008 121 sustainability. The Council also emphasised that giving consideration to disaster prevention meas- ures, in both the rehabilitation and development aid phases, is essential for the sustainability of the measures implemented. Bull. EU 10-2008 123 33. European neighbourhood policy General 1.33.1. Committee of the Regions opinion on the Commission communication on a strong Euro- pean neighbourhood policy. Commission communication: OJ C 106, 26.4.2008; COM(2007) 774; Bull. 12-2007, point 1.32.2 Adopted by the Committee of the Regions on 9 Oc- tober. Concerning political dialogue and decen- tralisation reforms, the Committee recalled its conviction that a prosperous and secure neigh- bourhood can only be achieved through an efficient cooperation at the local and regional level. Local and regional authorities are best placed to identify and address citizens’ needs and provide adequate services. The Committee called on European neighbourhood policy (ENP) countries to welcome international monitors to observe their elections in order to increase transparency of the election process and consequently improve the level of con- fidence of citizens in the democratic processes. Concerning mobility and migration, the Commit- tee reiterated that mobility and contacts between people are reinforcing the capacity of ENP coun- tries to benefit from economic integration, while progress on mutual understanding would be exceptionally difficult without increasing oppor- tunities for ENP citizens to travel to the EU. Concerning human rights and trafficking, the Committee noted considerable progress in the improvement of human rights and democracy since the beginning of the ENP and Euro- Mediterranean partnership programme and urged governments of ENP countries to continue embracing universal human rights as they consti- tute one of the core values of the EU. Concerning regional conflicts, the Committee reiterated that the EU has a direct interest in working with ENP countries in order to contribute to the resolution of so-called ‘frozen conflicts’ as they can undermine European’s security through regional escalation, unmanageable migratory flows and disruption of energy supply. Concerning the regional and multilateral fora, the Committee welcomed the proposal to build closer ties with the EU’s neighbours to the east (‘eastern partnership’) and called for the development of fora of local and regional authorities of Member States and European neighbourhood policy partner countries for the eastern dimension. The Commit- tee welcomed as well the relaunch of the Euro- Mediterranean partnership (‘union for the Mediter- ranean’) and stressed the importance of supporting dialogue between local and regional authorities of EU Member States and European neighbourhood policy partners in the southern Mediterranean.

Committee of the Regions opinion on ‘The Barcelona process: union for the Mediter- ranean’ — Implications for regional and local authorities’. References: Barcelona declaration and work programme: Bull. 11-1995, point 2.3.1 Outlook opinion of the Committee of the Regions on the ‘Euro-Mediterranean partnership and local and regional authorities: the need for coordination and a specific instrument for decen- tralised cooperation’: OJ C 121, 30.4.2004; Bull. 4- 2004, point 1.6.92 Committee of the Regions opinion on the Com- mission communication — ‘Tenth anniversary of the Euro-Mediterranean partnership: a work pro- gramme to meet the challenges of the next five years’: OJ C 81, 4.4.2006; Bull. 10-2005, point 1.6.41 Commission communication — ‘Barcelona process: union for the Mediterranean’: COM(2008) 319; Bull. 5-2008, point 1.35.2 Adopted by the Committee of the Regions on 9 October. The Committee underlined the impor- tance of the ‘Barcelona process: union for the Mediterranean’ initiative which has put the Mediterranean at the top of the European agenda and stimulated discussions and thinking com- mensurate with the stakes involved. The Com- mittee is convinced that initiatives focusing exclusively on a diplomatic approach from either side of the Mediterranean will not achieve sus- tainable solutions while local democracy is not put at the heart of the debate. It recalled that solu- tions should be devised at territorial level, in close cooperation with other institutional levels in order to simultaneously adjust and respond to the challenges posed by globalisation. Conse- quently, it repeated its call for local and regional authorities to be recognised as key partners in the Barcelona process and Euro-Mediterranean cooperation. The Committee thus decided to pro- mote the establishment of a Euro-Mediterranean regional and local assembly, made up of mem- bers of the Committee of the Regions, represen- tatives of European and international associations engaged in Euro-Mediterranean cooperation and an equal number of representatives of regional and local authorities from the southern and east- ern shores of the Mediterranean. It would act as a permanent platform for dialogue, exchange and cooperation. The Committee called for the recog- nition of this assembly as a consultative body within the future governance of the ‘Barcelona process: union for the Mediterranean’. 1.35.2. The Council welcomed the recent increase in the pace of EU relations with Moldova. It is ready to have a deeper relationship in the framework of the ENP and to negotiate a new and ambitious agree- ment with Moldova soon. This agreement will go beyond the current partnership and cooperation agreement, including the aim of a comprehensive and deep free-trade area, to be put in place when Moldova is ready to sustain the effects of full lib- eralisation of its trade with the EU. References: European Parliament resolution on the northern dimension: new action plan 2004–06: OJ C 38 E, 12.2.2004; Bull. 1/2-2003, point 1.6.124 European Parliament resolution on the northern dimension: OJ C 87 E, 7.4.2004; Bull. 11-2003, point 1.6.72 European Parliament resolution on a Baltic Sea region strategy for the northern dimension: Bull. 11-2006, point 1.33.31 Commission communication on an integrated maritime policy for the European Union: OJ C 55, 28.2.2008; COM(2007) 575; Bull. 10-2007, point 1.19.2 Adopted by the European Parliament on 9 Octo- ber. Parliament was deeply concerned by the effects of climate change on the sustainability of the lives of the indigenous peoples in the region, in terms of both the general environment and the natural habitat. It underlined that any interna- tional decisions relating to these issues must fully involve and take account of all peoples and nations of the Arctic. Parliament welcomes the fact that the ‘high north’ forms part of the EU’s northern dimension policy, but is convinced that awareness of the Arctic’s importance in a global context needs to be raised further by delivering a standalone EU Arctic policy. It awaits with great interest the forthcoming Commission communi- cation on Arctic policy, and called on the Com- mission to address the following issues: ¡ the state of play in relation to climate change, and adaptation to it, in the region; ¡ policy options that respect the indigenous populations and their livelihoods; ¡ the need to cooperate with Arctic neighbours on cross-border issues, in particular maritime safety; ¡ options for a future cross-border political or legal structure that could provide for the envi- ronmental protection and sustainable orderly development of the region or mediate political disagreement over resources and navigable water- ways in the high north. Parliament also called on the Commission to include energy and security policy in the Arctic region on its agenda. It remained particularly con- cerned over the ongoing race for natural resources in the Arctic, which may lead to secu- rity threats for the EU and overall international instability. Finally, Parliament urged the Com- mission to take a proactive role in the Arctic by taking up ‘observer status’ on the Arctic Council, and setting up a dedicated Arctic desk. Plenary session in Brussels, 8 and 9 October 1.38.2. Parliament held an extensive debate on the preparation of the European Council on 15 and 16 October, following statements from the Council and the Commission. The debate focused essentially on the financial crisis and was fairly consensual, albeit with nuances as to the specific measures to be taken. Although most Members called for concerted action by the EU and largely supported the conclusions of the Ecofin Council held on 7 October, some members in the left ranks criticised the lack of any preventive action in the past. Several MEPs went even further to attack Mr McCreevy, Member of the Commis- sion, for years of alleged inactivity. President Barroso, whilst underlining the need for more coordination between all relevant actors, pre- sented a string of Commission proposals in the pipeline and announced the creation of a high- level group on the future financial market super- visory architecture under the chairmanship of Mr de Larosière, former Director-General of the IMF, as well as the establishment of a permanent steering group on the financial crisis at Commis- sion level to be chaired by himself, and including Mr Almunia, Mr McCreevy and Mrs Kroes, Members of the Commission. State Secretary Jouyet, on behalf of the French Presidency, agreed that coordination still needed to be enhanced at EU level and expressed confidence in the Commission’s forthcoming proposals. He fur- ther expected the IMF to take on the role of ‘financial watchdog’ in order to ensure both financial and monetary stability at international level. The other key issues for debate included the Treaty of Lisbon, with members almost unan- imously calling for a speedy ratification by the remaining Member States and a clear roadmap for a solution of the Irish deadlock (at the latest at the December European Council). The House also discussed the energy and climate package, with a divergence of views between the Com- mission and the Council Presidency: whereas President Barroso rejected the claim that this package was unsuited for a situation of economic downturn, Mr Jouyet reiterated the idea that it had to be adapted to the current economic cir- cumstances, yet without bringing into question its broad principles. It is noteworthy that the PPE- DE group took a cautious approach, asking to ‘move forward carefully without scaring indus- try’. Should an additional year be necessary to come up with a balanced agreement, this addi- tional time should be taken. The formal sitting of the European Parliament was marked by a speech from Ingrid Betancourt, who described her traumatic experience in cap- tivity and made an appeal for raising global awareness of human rights violations (her speech coincided with the 60th anniversary of the UN Declaration on Human Rights). She concluded by praising the power of ‘words and dialogue’ as indispensable tools for bringing wars and human rights violations to an end. In the institutional field, the House held a debate on the implementation of the ruling of the Court of Justice on the Turco case regarding access to Council documents (legal opinions and delegation names). Mr Jouyet, in replying to the oral question on behalf of the Council, reassured the House that

European Parliament 150 Bull. EU 10-2008 the Council would fully comply with the ruling as well as with Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001, adding that the documents in question had already been made public. Mrs Wallström, Vice-President of the Commission, underscored the fact that transparency was at the forefront of the Commis- sion’s policies, with databases continuously updated and adapted to new technologies. As far as domestic policies are concerned, the debate focused on three main issues. The House adopted by a very large majority a resolution with recommendations to the Commission on ‘Lam- falussy follow-up’. It calls on the Commission to submit to Parliament, by the end of 2008, a leg- islative proposal covering the effective regulatory and supervisory arrangements for financial markets at European level as well as a wide range of meas- ures related to the proposed future financial stabil- ity and supervisory frameworks. Mr McCreevy, Member of the Commission, acknowledged that Europe was currently going through the most seri- ous financial crisis in living memory. The major challenge was to release lending throughout the economy. He reassured the House that several ini- tiatives were already under way or in the pipeline. The House reached a broad consensus on the challenge of water scarcity and droughts in the European Union. The House supported the pro- posed first set of policy initiatives. However it criticised the non-concrete nature of the envisaged set of objectives and the loose timetable for their implementation. Mr S pidla, Member of the Com- mission, welcomed that fact that the report endorsed, by and large, the measures put forward by the Commission, further recalling that the Council conclusions also went in a similar direc- tion. Parliament also adopted an own-initiative report on the Commission’s White Paper ‘Together for health: a strategic approach for the EU 2008–13’. The debate in the House gathered broad consen- sus, the White Paper being broadly welcomed. However some Members criticised the lack of more specific and quantifiable indicators. Mr McCreevy outlined the Commission’s plans in different areas related to health (nutrition, lifestyle, prevention, screening, centres of excel- lence, etc.) and reassured members that while the White Paper contained general goals and princi- ples, specific targets and quantifiable measures would be included in concrete policy initiatives. Under the new Rule 45(2) of its Rules of Proce- dure, Parliament discussed and adopted three own-initiative reports, with debates limited to short presentations by rapporteurs and replies by the Commission. The House carried by a large majority the report on stepping up the fight against undeclared work, very much supportive of the Commission’s approach. Mr S pidla stressed that the problem had already been highlighted in the Green Paper on labour law, mentioning two specific initiatives in this field: the draft directive on the application of the principle of equal treat- ment between men and women and the proposal on sanctions for employers of illegally resident third-country nationals. Parliament adopted a res- olution on the implementation of the social leg- islation related to road transport, with opposition from the PPE-DE ranks. Mr S pidla explained that the problem regarding the enforcement of the leg- islation in Member States lay within the existence of ‘false self-employed drivers’, who were only formally independent. The House also carried by a large majority the report on promoting social inclusion and combating poverty in the EU. Mr S pidla underlined that combating poverty was included in the renewed social agenda, pointing to the recently adopted recommendation on active inclusion. As far as external policies are concerned, the debate focused on the suspension of the Doha Round. In its resolution, Parliament reiterates its full commitment to the multilateral approach to trade policy, placing emphasis on the fact that, in the current context of financial crisis, a success- ful conclusion of the Doha Round could prove to be a stabilising factor. In the course of the debate, some members levelled strong criticism against Mr Mandelson’s resignation as Member of the Commission, which they deemed to represent a final blow to the Doha debacle. Mrs Fischer Boel, Member of the Commission, explained that although the July round of negotiations had failed, the Doha Round as such had not been sus- pended. The Commission’s aim was to act con- structively to facilitate a full ministerial resump- tion once the necessary assessments were carried out on those issues still outstanding. In the field of external policies, the House also adopted by an overwhelming majority resolu- tions on the situation in Belarus, Arctic gover- nance and Ukraine’s maritime commitments

Plenary session in Strasbourg, 20–23 October 1.38.3. In a formal sitting, Parliament was addressed by the former President of Portugal and current UN High Representative for the Alliance of Civilisations Mr Jorge Sampaio, who delivered a speech on cultural diversity in the framework of the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue. President Pöttering presented the Dardenne broth- ers, directors of the film Le silence de Lorna , with the Lux Prize 2008. He underlined that the prize was the expression of Parliament’s support for the cultural and linguistic diversity of the EU. Regarding the key debates, a significant share of the plenary session was devoted to the debate on the outcome of the European Council which had taken place in Brussels on 15 and 16 October. President Sarkozy, on behalf of the French Pres- idency, whilst recalling the disproportionate reac- tion taken by Russia vis-à-vis Georgia last Au- gust, stressed his belief in a long-term partnership of the EU with Russia. In turning to the financial crisis, he underlined that, unless speedy concerted action had been taken, the situation could well have led to the collapse of the financial system in Europe. He acknowledged that it had not been easy to assemble a coordinated European response, involving all the relevant stakeholders, namely the Commission, the biggest European economies, the European Central Bank and the Eurogroup, along with the United Kingdom and the Slovak Republic. Eventually consensus had been hammered out, including the spending of several hundred billion euro both to reassure European bank account holders and to restart interbank lending. The recipe for success was European cooperation, with a view to ensuring that Europe would not lose its industrial basis and European enterprises would not end up in the hands of non-Europeans. Regarding the energy and climate change package, President Sarkozy set out two absolute priorities: delivery on the 20- 20-20 commitments and agreement before Poz- na n . Europe would otherwise lose valuable growth opportunities from a first-mover position and its global partners would receive the wrong signal. Finally, in addressing the pact on immi- gration, which he deemed to represent a remark- able achievement among 27 Member States in troubled times, he recalled that such a pact would allow Member States leeway for flexibility within an agreed framework. He wound up by underlin- ing the need for strong European governance, notwithstanding its difficulties, especially in view of the delay in the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty. President Barroso congratulated Mr Sarkozy on his hard and successful work, adding that he was proud of being at the helm of the Commission, which had cooperated very closely with the French Presidency over the past weeks and months. He explained that Europe needed to overcome the financial crisis and then focus on the reform of the international financial system as well as on bolstering and re-launching the real

European Parliament 152 Bull. EU 10-2008 economy. A global response was needed to meet the global challenges. The next steps would involve the adoption of several measures by the Commission (already under way or in the pipeline) touching upon such aspects as capital requirements, the necessary guarantees for bank deposits and new accounting standards. He announced the composition of the newly created high-level group under the chairmanship of Mr Larosière, which would present its first find- ings for the spring 2009 European Council. He expressed his satisfaction over the agreement reached on the pact on immigration, adding that a similar compromise should be reached before the end of 2008 on the energy and climate change package. The main political groups aired positive views on the outcome of the European Council. The PPE- DE thanked the French Presidency for its efforts, thereby allowing Europe to play a remarkable role in the world. It also underlined that managing a financial crisis should not be tantamount to the end of capitalism. However, the free market had to be subject to appropriate regulation. The PSE brought to the fore the fact that the policy of unfet- tered financial deregulation had fallen into pieces, offering a great opportunity now for Europe to insist on a better financial system at the world level. In praising the work done by Mr Sarkozy and President Barroso, the PSE held that they had rallied to positions closer to the ones held by the PSE Group for many years. The ADLE raised con- cerns whether the European Council conclusions may jeopardise Parliament’s role in co-decision. It should be noted that, in the margins of the ple- nary, President Barroso attended an extraordinary meeting of the Conference of Presidents of polit- ical groups which was fully devoted to the finan- cial crisis. Group heads endorsed the initiatives undertaken by the Commission President to meet successfully the challenges posed by the finan- cial turmoil. In the institutional field, five issues were dis- cussed. In the first place, Parliament endorsed by a large majority (538 in favour, 40 against, 63 abstentions) the appointment of Baroness Ash- ton of Upholland as member of the European Commission. Parliament also adopted, by an overwhelming majority verging on unanimity, the report on the annual activities of the European Ombudsman, 2007. Parliament carried with broad support a resolu- tion on the monitoring of the application of Com- munity law. Mr Borg, Member of the Commis- sion, recalled that the correct application of Community law ranked high among the priorities of the Barroso Commission, which was vigilant in exercising its role of ‘guardian of the Treaties’.
