European Economic and Social Committee 448th plenary session 1.38.17. The European Economic and Social Com- mittee held its 448th plenary session on 22 and 23 October, chaired by Mr Sepi (Employees Group), who was elected President, taking over from Mr Dimitriadis for the 2008–10 term. Mrs Pari (Employers Group) and Mr Kallio (Vari- ous Interests Group) were elected Vice-Presidents. In his inaugural speech, underpinned by a new focus on the future, the President first called for the speedy ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon. At a time of change within the European institu- tions, he stressed the advisory role of the Com- mittee, making full use of the popular right of ini- tiative and putting into practice the requirement to consult and inform civil society. He also expressed his intention to build more structured relationships with the European Parliament and the Council, along the lines of the protocol with the Commission, and improve cooperation with the Committee of the Regions and national par- liaments. In this time of crisis, the Committee should insist on its role and ambition to become a bridge between Europe and civil society, thus bridging the gap between citizens and institu- tions. In this context, the President intends to hold a conference to bring together banks, industry and civil society. The President’s programme will tackle three priorities: ¡ the Lisbon Treaty and the question of partic- ipatory democracy, which must be translated into legislation. The Committee should also insist on the application of the Charter of Rights contained in the Treaty, and its role in responding to the problems of immigration; ¡ the European social model, which not only exists but is also sustainable and working; ¡ the Lisbon strategy, which is the most effec- tive response to the challenge of globalisation. It will have to be renewed based on synergy between programmes and coordinated action on economic policy, social progress and respect for the environment. The Community method should

Committee of the Regions 162 Bull. EU 10-2008 be favoured, with the Committee using the net- work of national committees that it has created. A prerequisite to the President’s priorities is assessing the real impact of European policies. In parallel, the Committee must develop an effec- tive internal and external communication strategy. Mr S pidla, Member of the Commission, took part in the debate on ‘Rights and solidarity to guide globalisation’. He lent his full support to the pri- orities of the new presidency. He underlined the key role of the Committee and encouraged exploratory opinions. The Committee adopted 32 opinions, including 3 exploratory opinions and 11 initiative opinions. The opinion on the ethical and social dimension of the financial institutions was largely amended in relation to the current crisis. The Committee debated models for global trade and financial relationships. Members regretted the simplistic vision laid out in the amendment and volunteered to work on a more balanced project. Others blamed the advocates of rampant liberalism and market self-regulation, and considered that it was high time for review, with actual supervision of the financial institutions. Regrets were expressed on the gap between the reality of the situation and this opinion, considered it as philosophical and not fit to meet current needs, asking for the opin- ion to be given added strength and postponed. Members suggested preparing a resolution to be adopted in December. Nevertheless, this opinion was adopted by a weak majority. Members debated the ‘medical check-up’ of the CAP. The adopted opinion, which had a broader outlook than the Commission proposal, called for a more detailed analysis of possible future devel- opments in the dairy market as the current legis- lation on milk quotas is to expire in 2015. The Committee advocated setting up a European milk network in order to bring supply into line with demand. The opinion on the Northern Ireland peace process emphasised the role of the EU, through the PEACE programme, as being unprecedented in history. It recalled that the EU funds helped support the efforts of civil society towards rec- onciliation between communities. The opinion on the EU and the global food chal- lenge was drawn up upon request by the French Presidency. Members agreed such a topic was too challenging for a simple opinion. The information report on development with equity and environmental responsibility met wide approval. Committee of the Regions 76th plenary session 1.38.18. The Committee of the Regions held its 76th session, on 8 and 9 October , in the frame- work of the sixth Open Days, in the presence of numerous local and regional political leaders. The meeting devoted a great deal of attention to polit- ical discussions, charged both with hope and con- cerns. The Committee adopted 15 opinions. Mr Van den Brande, President of the Commit- tee, welcomed Ms Mavrou, Representative of the Greco-Cypriot community in Nicosia, and Mr Cagakan, representative of the Turco-Cypriot Community of the city. He stated that he was par- ticularly proud to be able to receive them together at this historic moment, contributing in this way to a strengthening of mutual confidence. He stressed the importance of the local authorities’ initiatives leading to remarkable results and passed on all the Committee’s solidarity with their efforts. The two Cypriot participants reaffirmed their agreement to work together towards the common aim of peace and cohesion by forgetting the dis- agreements which separated both communities. They also evoked the Committee’s role which helps fill the gap between citizens and institutions. The political groups underlined their mutual obli- gation towards the alignment of the communities and hope that these first steps stimulate a more ambitious development for the future. Ms Hübner, Member of the Commission, sub- mitted the Green Paper concerning territorial cohesion during the opening session of the Open Days. She stressed that this initiative supported the territorial diversity of the EU as a vital asset

Committee of the Regions Bull. EU 10-2008 163 and that it was likely to contribute, generally, to the durability of its development, to the access to quality public services for all and to economic growth and employment. Ms Hübner declared that this initiative, in addition, launched the debate on territorial cohesion as a basis for study for the future of the regional policy post-2013. The result should achieve better comprehension of the diver- sity of the subject and a better evaluation of its implications on the policy implemented. Mr Verheugen, Vice-President of the Commission, commented on the current financial crisis and informed local representatives that regions would probably be the first actors most affected. In the current state of markets, the urgency was to return confidence to citizens to prevent the spread of the problem. According to him, the EU is better armed than other parts of the world in this context: a very developed internal market, which makes it possi- ble to contain dependence in relation to the fluc- tuations of the world markets and which seeks the continuation of enlargement; a single currency in the ‘euro area’, which encourages stronger dynam- ics than elsewhere; a growth and employment strategy, which is based on mechanisms which make it possible to progress; decisions which should be taken at the next European Council with a view to meeting the needs for better governance. This difficult economic situation has to encourage Europe to act for SMEs, in view of their growth potential to be developed. Mr Verheugen put the emphasis on the importance of reaffirming the objectives laid down, of getting rid of certain obstacles and of connecting the ecological con- straints to the economic objectives. Mr Verheugen recalled that the ‘Small Business Act’, which envisages numerous instruments, will constitute the basis of the rebuilding of companies, with the aid of the EIB which agrees to put more means in terms of provisions to guarantee the access of SMEs to new outlets. The draft opinion on proposals concerning the CAP, following the ‘medical check-up’, supports the position of the Commission (to loosen the link between direct subsidies and production lev- els more in order to allow producers better access to markets) while stressing a careful approach which makes it possible to avoid volatile markets and which take account of regional differences and production systems. Producers do not have to make the payments of the aid reform of the CAP, and the rapporteur proposes an annual increase in the quota of 2%. As regards the com- plexity of the matter, and considering that the amended text would make it possible to ensure a better level of durability, the rapporteur invited the Committee to adopt a common front in order to give a clear message with respect to the posi- tion of the Commission. The debate demonstrated the disparity of the positions and the divergences in regional inter- ests. It resulted in a high number of amendments. Some members commented on the annual increase in the quotas, on the importance given to the regions and on the new correlations between market prices and milk quotas. Members were alerted to the risk of depletion of a rare resource. According to them, the CAP does not have the role to support territorial cohesion pacts inside the ERDF. Finally, the amended report was adopted. The partnership as regards governance and plan- ning of projects in the field of regional policy gave the Committee the opportunity to reaffirm that the current model of governance of the structural policy constitutes a good base to determine its future orientation. The Committee points out that in the absence of methodology common to the whole of Europe regarding recourse to partnerships (to draw up, carry out, follow and evaluate the programming documents and planning on regional planning), it is not pos- sible to evaluate if a partnership were really incorporated into the step nor to see what the genuine impact was. The opinion drawn up on the exchange of emis- sion quotas had the role of influencing the result of the current co-decision procedure. It therefore has a strong political connotation: whilst wanting to support a sustainable economy, it wants also to protect the competitiveness of industry (SME) as well as the interests of consumers, by introducing new actors (including the transport sector) into the system of exchange of quotas. Some participants decided against the Commis- sion proposal by stressing that the reduction in the incomes of companies could well involve them also reducing their investments in innova- tion and in environmental protective measures. According to the speakers, the measures proposed

Committee of the Regions 164 Bull. EU 10-2008 by the Commission are likely to involve signifi- cant deterioration in employment and it is espe- cially important to defend the competitive posi- tion of the European policy. Following the withdrawal of some amendments, the project was adopted. During the discussions, the opinion on industrial emissions was approved, without amendments. The Committee supports without reservation the prevention of pollution and the ‘polluter-payer’ principle; consequently, it favourably welcomed the objective of the directive on industrial emis- sions. The directive on this subject constitutes an important measure to make it possible for Mem- ber States to achieve their objectives as regards reduction of emissions between now and 2020, but the Committee considers that as regards air pollution, the directive is not ambitious enough. The opinion on the promotion of energy use pro- duced from renewable sources was the subject of several amendments due to various forums, in particular in Parliament, where the project was discussed. The final version takes account of the results of all these discussions. The Committee approved the opinion at a Euro- pean action level for job mobility (2007–10). It provided strong support for the position of the Commission. It stresses that ‘mobility’ has to be included and promoted as much in terms of geo- graphical mobility (within the Member States and among themselves) as in terms of economic and social mobility or of mobility in the labour mar- ket. Lastly, the Committee argued for the removal of all the legal and administrative obstacles to freedom of movement of the labour force by the end of the action plan, in 2011, including for the new Member States (Bulgaria and Romania). In the field of foreign affairs, an opinion on a strong European neighbourhood policy was also approved. The Committee reaffirmed here its conviction according to which a prosperous and secure neighbourhood necessarily involves an effective cooperation at the local and regional level; consequently it calls on the countries con- cerned with the European neighbourhood policy (ENP) to give a favourable response to interna- tional observers who are responsible for follow- ing their elections, in order to strengthen the transparency of the electoral process and so improve the degree of citizens’ confidence in the democratic processes. The opinion on the Barcelona process: ‘A union for the Mediterranean’ favourably welcomed certain measures and initiatives that this process has so far generated; nevertheless, it regrets the lack of significant projections in the field of peace, security, human and social development, and the lack of involvement of local and regional authorities. In the field of education to the media, the Com- mission communication on the online creative contents received a favourable reception. On this basis, the Committee supports the priorities and the objectives laid down by the Commission on the matter and underlines precisely that education to the media involves citizens’ support for active and creative use of the media (and especially regarding the young generation), the support of citizens’ critical approach with regard to all media, the promotion of diversity of points of view in the media and the contribution to the dis- cussion relating to commercial notices and to questions related to respect and on the protection of privacy. Still in the same field, the opinion on a pro- gramme for a safer Internet proposes a whole series of amendments to the Commission pro- posal: to better advertise direct lines (hotlines) to end-users and to benefit from the possibilities of dissemination of essential information from local authorities. It also suggests, on the one hand, intensifying cooperation between direct lines, repressive services and Internet service providers and, on the other hand, involving other actors such as suitable social organisms and NGOs. Lastly, it recommends that programmes of com- puter teaching and of education to the media also attach an appropriate importance to a secure online environment and makes clear the dangers of illicit contents and prejudicial behaviour. In the opinion on citizens’ rights: ‘promotion of the fundamental rights and of the rights deriving from European citizenship’ the Committee observed that the European model of protection of fundamental rights, such as arising in particular from the Charter, appears among the most advanced because it includes civil and political laws and economic, social and cultural rights. The
